text: In this state of schemes , and hopes , and connivance , June opened upon Hartfield .
text_tokenized: In this state of schemes , and hopes , and connivance , June opened upon Hartfield .

text: To Highbury in general it brought no material change .
text_tokenized: To Highbury in general it brought no material change .

text: The Eltons were still talking of a visit from the Sucklings , and of the use to be made of their barouche - landau ; and Jane Fairfax was still at her grandmother 's ; and as the return of the Campbells from Ireland was again delayed , and August , instead of Midsummer , fixed for it , she was likely to remain there full two months longer , provided at least she were able to defeat Mrs. Elton 's activity in her service , and save herself from being hurried into a delightful situation against her will . Mr. Knightley , who , for some reason best known to himself , had certainly taken an early dislike to Frank Churchill , was only growing to dislike him more . He began to suspect him of some double dealing in his pursuit of Emma .
text_tokenized: The Eltons were still talking of a visit from the Sucklings , and of the use to be made of their barouche - landau ; and Jane Fairfax was still at her grandmother 's ; and as the return of the Campbells from Ireland was again delayed , and August , instead of Midsummer , fixed for it , she was likely to remain there full two months longer , provided at least she were able to defeat Mrs. Elton 's activity in her service , and save herself from being hurried into a delightful situation against her will . Mr. Knightley , who , for some reason best known to himself , had certainly taken an early dislike to Frank Churchill , was only growing to dislike him more . He began to suspect him of some double dealing in his pursuit of Emma .

text: That Emma was his object appeared indisputable .
text_tokenized: That Emma was his object appeared indisputable .

text: Every thing declared it ; his own attentions , his father 's hints , his mother - in - law 's guarded silence ; it was all in unison ; words , conduct , discretion , and indiscretion , told the same story .
text_tokenized: Every thing declared it ; his own attentions , his father 's hints , his mother - in - law 's guarded silence ; it was all in unison ; words , conduct , discretion , and indiscretion , told the same story .

text: But while so many were devoting him to Emma , and Emma herself making him over to Harriet , Mr. Knightley began to suspect him of some inclination to trifle with Jane Fairfax .
text_tokenized: But while so many were devoting him to Emma , and Emma herself making him over to Harriet , Mr. Knightley began to suspect him of some inclination to trifle with Jane Fairfax .

text: He could not understand it ; but there were symptoms of intelligence between them -- he thought so at least-- symptoms of admiration on his side , which , having once observed , he could not persuade himself to think entirely void of meaning , however he might wish to escape any of Emma 's errors of imagination . _ She _ was not present when the suspicion first arose .

text: He was dining with the Randalls family , and Jane , at the Eltons ' ; and he had seen a look , more than a single look , at Miss Fairfax , which , from the admirer of Miss Woodhouse , seemed somewhat out of place .
text_tokenized: He was dining with the Randalls family , and Jane , at the Eltons ' ; and he had seen a look , more than a single look , at Miss Fairfax , which , from the admirer of Miss Woodhouse , seemed somewhat out of place .

text: When he was again in their company , he could not help remembering what he had seen ; nor could he avoid observations which , unless it were like Cowper and his fire at twilight , " Myself creating what I saw , " brought him yet stronger suspicion of there being a something of private liking , of private understanding even , between Frank Churchill and Jane .

text: He had walked up one day after dinner , as he very often did , to spend his evening at Hartfield .
text_tokenized: He had walked up one day after dinner , as he very often did , to spend his evening at Hartfield .

text: Emma and Harriet were going to walk ; he joined them ; and , on returning , they fell in with a larger party , who , like themselves , judged it wisest to take their exercise early , as the weather threatened rain ; Mr. and Mrs. Weston and their son , Miss Bates and her niece , who had accidentally met .
text_tokenized: Emma and Harriet were going to walk ; he joined them ; and , on returning , they fell in with a larger party , who , like themselves , judged it wisest to take their exercise early , as the weather threatened rain ; Mr. and Mrs. Weston and their son , Miss Bates and her niece , who had accidentally met .

text: They all united ; and , on reaching Hartfield gates , Emma , who knew it was exactly the sort of visiting that would be welcome to her father , pressed them all to go in and drink tea with him .
text_tokenized: They all united ; and , on reaching Hartfield gates , Emma , who knew it was exactly the sort of visiting that would be welcome to her father , pressed them all to go in and drink tea with him .

text: The Randalls party agreed to it immediately ; and after a pretty long speech from Miss Bates , which few persons listened to , she also found it possible to accept dear Miss Woodhouse 's most obliging invitation .
text_tokenized: The Randalls party agreed to it immediately ; and after a pretty long speech from Miss Bates , which few persons listened to , she also found it possible to accept dear Miss Woodhouse 's most obliging invitation .

text: As they were turning into the grounds , Mr. Perry passed by on horseback .
text_tokenized: As they were turning into the grounds , Mr. Perry passed by on horseback .

text: The gentlemen spoke of his horse .
text_tokenized: The gentlemen spoke of his horse .

text: " By the bye , " said Frank Churchill to Mrs. Weston presently , " what became of Mr. Perry 's plan of setting up his carriage ? "
text_tokenized: " By the bye , " said Frank Churchill to Mrs. Weston presently , " what became of Mr. Perry 's plan of setting up his carriage ? "

text: Mrs. Weston looked surprized , and said , " I did not know that he ever had any such plan . " " Nay , I had it from you .
text_tokenized: Mrs. Weston looked surprized , and said , " I did not know that he ever had any such plan . " " Nay , I had it from you .

text: You wrote me word of it three months ago .
text_tokenized: You wrote me word of it three months ago .

text: " Me ! impossible ! " " Indeed you did .
text_tokenized: " Me ! impossible ! " " Indeed you did .

text: I remember it perfectly .
text_tokenized: I remember it perfectly .

text: You mentioned it as what was certainly to be very soon .
text_tokenized: You mentioned it as what was certainly to be very soon .

text: Mrs. Perry had told somebody , and was extremely happy about it .
text_tokenized: Mrs. Perry had told somebody , and was extremely happy about it .

text: It was owing to _ her _ persuasion , as she thought his being out in bad weather did him a great deal of harm .
text_tokenized: It was owing to _ her _ persuasion , as she thought his being out in bad weather did him a great deal of harm .

text: You must remember it now ?
text_tokenized: You must remember it now ?

text: " Upon my word I never heard of it till this moment . " " Never !
text_tokenized: " Upon my word I never heard of it till this moment . " " Never !

text: really , never!--Bless me !
text_tokenized: really , never!--Bless me !

text: Miss Smith , you walk as if you were tired . You will not be sorry to find yourself at home . "
text_tokenized: Miss Smith , you walk as if you were tired . You will not be sorry to find yourself at home . "

text: " What is this?--What is this ? " cried Mr. Weston , " about Perry and a carriage ?
text_tokenized: " What is this?--What is this ? " cried Mr. Weston , " about Perry and a carriage ?

text: Is Perry going to set up his carriage , Frank ?
text_tokenized: Is Perry going to set up his carriage , Frank ?

text: I am glad he can afford it .
text_tokenized: I am glad he can afford it .

text: You had it from himself , had you ? "
text_tokenized: You had it from himself , had you ? "

text: " No , sir , " replied his son , laughing , " I seem to have had it from nobody.--Very odd!--I really was persuaded of Mrs. Weston 's having mentioned it in one of her letters to Enscombe , many weeks ago , with all these particulars -- but as she declares she never heard a syllable of it before , of course it must have been a dream . I am a great dreamer .
text_tokenized: " No , sir , " replied his son , laughing , " I seem to have had it from nobody.--Very odd!--I really was persuaded of Mrs. Weston 's having mentioned it in one of her letters to Enscombe , many weeks ago , with all these particulars -- but as she declares she never heard a syllable of it before , of course it must have been a dream . I am a great dreamer .

text: I dream of every body at Highbury when I am away-- and when I have gone through my particular friends , then I begin dreaming of Mr. and Mrs. Perry .
text_tokenized: I dream of every body at Highbury when I am away-- and when I have gone through my particular friends , then I begin dreaming of Mr. and Mrs. Perry .

text: " " It is odd though , " observed his father , " that you should have had such a regular connected dream about people whom it was not very likely you should be thinking of at Enscombe .
text_tokenized: " " It is odd though , " observed his father , " that you should have had such a regular connected dream about people whom it was not very likely you should be thinking of at Enscombe .

text: Perry 's setting up his carriage ! and his wife 's persuading him to it , out of care for his health-- just what will happen , I have no doubt , some time or other ; only a little premature .
text_tokenized: Perry 's setting up his carriage ! and his wife 's persuading him to it , out of care for his health-- just what will happen , I have no doubt , some time or other ; only a little premature .

text: What an air of probability sometimes runs through a dream !
text_tokenized: What an air of probability sometimes runs through a dream !

text: And at others , what a heap of absurdities it is !
text_tokenized: And at others , what a heap of absurdities it is !

text: Well , Frank , your dream certainly shews that Highbury is in your thoughts when you are absent .
text_tokenized: Well , Frank , your dream certainly shews that Highbury is in your thoughts when you are absent .

text: Emma , you are a great dreamer , I think ? "
text_tokenized: Emma , you are a great dreamer , I think ? "

text: Emma was out of hearing .
text_tokenized: Emma was out of hearing .

text: She had hurried on before her guests to prepare her father for their appearance , and was beyond the reach of Mr. Weston 's hint .
text_tokenized: She had hurried on before her guests to prepare her father for their appearance , and was beyond the reach of Mr. Weston 's hint .

text: " Why , to own the truth , " cried Miss Bates , who had been trying in vain to be heard the last two minutes , " if I must speak on this subject , there is no denying that Mr. Frank Churchill might have -- I do not mean to say that he did not dream it -- I am sure I have sometimes the oddest dreams in the world -- but if I am questioned about it , I must acknowledge that there was such an idea last spring ; for Mrs. Perry herself mentioned it to my mother , and the Coles knew of it as well as ourselves -- but it was quite a secret , known to nobody else , and only thought of about three days .
text_tokenized: " Why , to own the truth , " cried Miss Bates , who had been trying in vain to be heard the last two minutes , " if I must speak on this subject , there is no denying that Mr. Frank Churchill might have -- I do not mean to say that he did not dream it -- I am sure I have sometimes the oddest dreams in the world -- but if I am questioned about it , I must acknowledge that there was such an idea last spring ; for Mrs. Perry herself mentioned it to my mother , and the Coles knew of it as well as ourselves -- but it was quite a secret , known to nobody else , and only thought of about three days .

text: Mrs. Perry was very anxious that he should have a carriage , and came to my mother in great spirits one morning because she thought she had prevailed .
text_tokenized: Mrs. Perry was very anxious that he should have a carriage , and came to my mother in great spirits one morning because she thought she had prevailed .

text: Jane , do n't you remember grandmama 's telling us of it when we got home ? I forget where we had been walking to-- very likely to Randalls ; yes , I think it was to Randalls .
text_tokenized: Jane , do n't you remember grandmama 's telling us of it when we got home ? I forget where we had been walking to-- very likely to Randalls ; yes , I think it was to Randalls .

text: Mrs. Perry was always particularly fond of my mother -- indeed I do not know who is not -- and she had mentioned it to her in confidence ; she had no objection to her telling us , of course , but it was not to go beyond : and , from that day to this , I never mentioned it to a soul that I know of .
text_tokenized: Mrs. Perry was always particularly fond of my mother -- indeed I do not know who is not -- and she had mentioned it to her in confidence ; she had no objection to her telling us , of course , but it was not to go beyond : and , from that day to this , I never mentioned it to a soul that I know of .

text: At the same time , I will not positively answer for my having never dropt a hint , because I know I do sometimes pop out a thing before I am aware .
text_tokenized: At the same time , I will not positively answer for my having never dropt a hint , because I know I do sometimes pop out a thing before I am aware .

text: I am a talker , you know ; I am rather a talker ; and now and then I have let a thing escape me which I should not .

text: I am not like Jane ; I wish I were .

text: There was no time for farther remark or explanation .

text: The dream must be borne with , and Mr. Knightley must take his seat with the rest round the large modern circular table which Emma had introduced at Hartfield , and which none but Emma could have had power to place there and persuade her father to use , instead of the small - sized Pembroke , on which two of his daily meals had , for forty years been crowded . Tea passed pleasantly , and nobody seemed in a hurry to move .

text: " Miss Woodhouse , " said Frank Churchill , after examining a table behind him , which he could reach as he sat , " have your nephews taken away their alphabets -- their box of letters ? It used to stand here .

text_tokenized: Where is it ?

text: This is a sort of dull - looking evening , that ought to be treated rather as winter than summer .

text: The quietness of the game made it particularly eligible for Mr. Woodhouse , who had often been distressed by the more animated sort , which Mr. Weston had occasionally introduced , and who now sat happily occupied in lamenting , with tender melancholy , over the departure of the " poor little boys , " or in fondly pointing out , as he took up any stray letter near him , how beautifully Emma had written it . Frank Churchill placed a word before Miss Fairfax .

text: The word was _ blunder _ ; and as Harriet exultingly proclaimed it , there was a blush on Jane 's cheek which gave it a meaning not otherwise ostensible .

text: How the delicacy , the discretion of his favourite could have been so lain asleep ! He feared there must be some decided involvement .

text: Disingenuousness and double dealing seemed to meet him at every turn . These letters were but the vehicle for gallantry and trick .

text: It was a child 's play , chosen to conceal a deeper game on Frank Churchill 's part .
text_tokenized: It was a child 's play , chosen to conceal a deeper game on Frank Churchill 's part .

text: With great indignation did he continue to observe him ; with great alarm and distrust , to observe also his two blinded companions .
text_tokenized: With great indignation did he continue to observe him ; with great alarm and distrust , to observe also his two blinded companions .

text: He saw a short word prepared for Emma , and given to her with a look sly and demure .
text_tokenized: He saw a short word prepared for Emma , and given to her with a look sly and demure .

text: He saw that Emma had soon made it out , and found it highly entertaining , though it was something which she judged it proper to appear to censure ; for she said , " Nonsense ! for shame ! "
text_tokenized: He saw that Emma had soon made it out , and found it highly entertaining , though it was something which she judged it proper to appear to censure ; for she said , " Nonsense ! for shame ! "

text: He heard Frank Churchill next say , with a glance towards Jane , " I will give it to her -- shall I?"--and as clearly heard Emma opposing it with eager laughing warmth . " No , no , you must not ; you shall not , indeed . " It was done however .

text: This gallant young man , who seemed to love without feeling , and to recommend himself without complaisance , directly handed over the word to Miss Fairfax , and with a particular degree of sedate civility entreated her to study it .

text: Mr. Knightley 's excessive curiosity to know what this word might be , made him seize every possible moment for darting his eye towards it , and it was not long before he saw it to be _ Dixon _ .

text: Jane Fairfax 's perception seemed to accompany his ; her comprehension was certainly more equal to the covert meaning , the superior intelligence , of those five letters so arranged . She was evidently displeased ; looked up , and seeing herself watched , blushed more deeply than he had ever perceived her , and saying only , " I did not know that proper names were allowed , " pushed away the letters with even an angry spirit , and looked resolved to be engaged by no other word that could be offered .
text_tokenized: Jane Fairfax 's perception seemed to accompany his ; her comprehension was certainly more equal to the covert meaning , the superior intelligence , of those five letters so arranged . text: Her face was averted from those who had made the attack , and turned towards her aunt .

text: It is time for us to be going indeed .
text_tokenized: It is time for us to be going indeed .

text: The evening is closing in , and grandmama will be looking for us .

text: Jane 's alertness in moving , proved her as ready as her aunt had preconceived .

text: She was immediately up , and wanting to quit the table ; but so many were also moving , that she could not get away ; and Mr. Knightley thought he saw another collection of letters anxiously pushed towards her , and resolutely swept away by her unexamined . She was afterwards looking for her shawl -- Frank Churchill was looking also -- it was growing dusk , and the room was in confusion ; and how they parted , Mr. Knightley could not tell .

text: He remained at Hartfield after all the rest , his thoughts full of what he had seen ; so full , that when the candles came to assist his observations , he must -- yes , he certainly must , as a friend-- an anxious friend -- give Emma some hint , ask her some question .

text: He could not see her in a situation of such danger , without trying to preserve her . It was his duty .

text: " Pray , Emma , " said he , " may I ask in what lay the great amusement , the poignant sting of the last word given to you and Miss Fairfax ?
text_tokenized: " Pray , Emma , " said he , " may I ask in what lay the great amusement , the poignant sting of the last word given to you and Miss Fairfax ?

text: I saw the word , and am curious to know how it could be so very entertaining to the one , and so very distressing to the other . " Emma was extremely confused . She could not endure to give him the true explanation ; for though her suspicions were by no means removed , she was really ashamed of having ever imparted them . " Oh ! " she cried in evident embarrassment , " it all meant nothing ; a mere joke among ourselves . " " The joke , " he replied gravely , " seemed confined to you and Mr. Churchill . " He had hoped she would speak again , but she did not .

text: She would rather busy herself about any thing than speak .
text_tokenized: She would rather busy herself about any thing than speak .

text: He sat a little while in doubt .
text_tokenized: He sat a little while in doubt .

text: A variety of evils crossed his mind .
text_tokenized: A variety of evils crossed his mind .

text: Interference-- fruitless interference .
text_tokenized: Interference-- fruitless interference .

text: Emma 's confusion , and the acknowledged intimacy , seemed to declare her affection engaged . Yet he would speak .
text_tokenized: Emma 's confusion , and the acknowledged intimacy , seemed to declare her affection engaged . Yet he would speak .

text: He owed it to her , to risk any thing that might be involved in an unwelcome interference , rather than her welfare ; to encounter any thing , rather than the remembrance of neglect in such a cause .

text: " I have lately imagined that I saw symptoms of attachment between them-- certain expressive looks , which I did not believe meant to be public . "

text: I am delighted to find that you can vouchsafe to let your imagination wander -- but it will not do-- very sorry to check you in your first essay -- but indeed it will not do .
text_tokenized: I am delighted to find that you can vouchsafe to let your imagination wander -- but it will not do-- very sorry to check you in your first essay -- but indeed it will not do .

text: There is no admiration between them , I do assure you ; and the appearances which have caught you , have arisen from some peculiar circumstances -- feelings rather of a totally different nature-- it is impossible exactly to explain:--there is a good deal of nonsense in it -- but the part which is capable of being communicated , which is sense , is , that they are as far from any attachment or admiration for one another , as any two beings in the world can be .

text: She spoke with a confidence which staggered , with a satisfaction which silenced , Mr. Knightley .

text: She was in gay spirits , and would have prolonged the conversation , wanting to hear the particulars of his suspicions , every look described , and all the where s and how s of a circumstance which highly entertained her : but his gaiety did not meet hers .

text: He found he could not be useful , and his feelings were too much irritated for talking .

text: That he might not be irritated into an absolute fever , by the fire which Mr. Woodhouse 's tender habits required almost every evening throughout the year , he soon afterwards took a hasty leave , and walked home to the coolness and solitude of Donwell Abbey .
